questions.question: She is ……………… a promotion.
questions.description: Before a noun we use hope for or wait for. Expect is used without for.

questions.question: I am ………………… Maria to come in the evening.
questions.description: If we expect something to happen we have a good reason to believe that it will happen.

questions.question: I am ………………… to hear from her.
questions.description: All three of these verbs are possible before a to-infinitive with somewhat similar meanings.

questions.question: He ……………….. to get a bike for his birthday.
questions.description: Either hopes or expects is possible here.

questions.question: I have been ………………. for her for hours.
questions.description: We wait when somebody or something is late.

questions.question: We are ………………….. rain soon.
questions.description: Before a noun we use hope for or wait for. Expect is used without for.

questions.question: We are ………………… to get good rains this year.
questions.description: Before a to-infinitive, all of the above are possible.

questions.question: She is quite shy. I ………………….. her to be smarter.
questions.description: Before object + infinitive we use hope for or wait for. Expect is used without for.

questions.question: Employees are ………………… to start work at 9 o’clock.
questions.description: Expect is often used with object + infinitive to talk about people’s duties. Passive forms of this structure are also common.

questions.question: We are …………………. that you can come and stay with us.
questions.description: Progressive forms of expect are not normally used before a that-clause.

questions.question: We ………………. to hear from her today.
questions.description: Before a to-infinitive simple and continuous forms of hope and expect are used with very similar meanings.
